tit.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin としました。タイトルの際にTheを削除

sen.j: 山陰本線（さんいんほんせん）は、京都府京都市下京区の京都駅から福知山駅、鳥取駅、米子駅、出雲市駅、長門市駅を経て山口県下関市の幡生駅に至る西日本旅客鉄道（JR西日本）の鉄道路線（幹線）である（ただし幡生側の列車は下関駅まで運転）。
sen.e: The San'in Main Line is the railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that connects Kyoto Station (located in Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture) and Hatabu Station (located in Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) via Fukuchiyama Station, Tottori Station, Yonago Station, Izumoshi Station and Nagatoshi Station (trains bound for Hatabu Station, however, run farther to Shimonoseki Station).

The San'in Main Line is a railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that connects Kyoto Station (located in Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture) and Hatabu Station (located in Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) via Fukuchiyama Station, Tottori Station, Yonago Station, Izumoshi Station and Nagatoshi Station (trains bound for Hatabu Station, however, run farther to Shimonoseki Station).

The Sanin Main Line is a railway line (trunk line) operated by the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that connects Kyoto Station, located in Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and Hatabu Station, located in Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, via Fukuchiyama Station, Tottori Station, Yonago Station, Izumoshi Station and Nagatoshi Station (trains bound for Hatabu Station, however, run farther to Shimonoseki Station).
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin としました。

sen.j: このほか、仙崎支線あるいは仙崎線と呼ばれる長門市駅～仙崎駅間の支線を持つ。
sen.e: In addition, it has a branch line, called the Senzaki Branch Line or the Senzaki Line, that connects Nagatoshi Station and Senzaki Station.
Additionally, it has a branch line, called the Senzaki Branch Line or the Senzaki Line, that connects Nagatoshi Station and Senzaki Station.
Additionally, it has a branch line, called the Senzaki Branch Line or the Senzaki Line, that connects Nagatoshi Station and Senzaki Station.

sen.j: 京都～園部駅間が大都市近郊区間に含まれる。
sen.e: Kyoto⇔Sonobe section is included in the metropolitan suburban section.
The Kyoto⇔Sonobe section is included in the metropolitan suburban section.
The line between Kyoto and Sonobe runs through the urban neighborhood.
sen.cmt: レビュー結果の翻訳を参考にしました。

sen.j: 京都～園部間には嵯峨野線という愛称があり、京都駅などでは両者を併せて嵯峨野山陰線と案内することもある。
sen.e: Kyoto ⇔ Sonobe section has a nickname of the Sagano Line and the staff of Kyoto Station sometimes guide passengers by using the combined name of the Sagano-San'in Line.
The Kyoto ⇔ Sonobe section is nicknamed the Sagano Line, and the staff of Kyoto Station sometimes guide passengers by using the combined name of "Sagano-San'in Line."
The above section is nicknamed the Sagano Line, and the staff of Kyoto Station sometimes guide passengers by using the combined name of "Sagano-Sanin Line."
sen.cmt: Kyoto⇔Sonobe →The above section としました（前出のため）。アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin としました。

sen.j: その嵯峨野線各駅ではJスルー・ICOCA、及び東日本旅客鉄道（JR東日本）のSuica、東海旅客鉄道（JR東海）のTOICA、またスルッとKANSAIのPiTaPaが使用できる。
sen.e: At each station of the Sagano Line, J-THRU・ICOCA, Suica of East Japan Railway Company (JR East), TOICA of Central Japan Railway Company (JR Central) and PiTaPa of KANSAI THRU PASS are available.
At each station of the Sagano Line, J-THRU・ICOCA, Suica of East Japan Railway Company (JR East), TOICA of Central Japan Railway Company (JR Central) and PiTaPa of KANSAI THRU PASS are available.
At each station of the Sagano Line, J-Through/ICOCA, Suica of East Japan Railway Company (JR East), TOICA of Central Japan Railway Company (JR Central) and PiTaPa of KANSAI THRU PASS can be used.
sen.cmt: J-Through としました。Can be used としました。

sen.j: 京都と丹波国・但馬国地方および山陰地方の各都市を結んでいる。
sen.e: This line links Kyoto with Tanba Province, Tajima Province and cities of San'in area.

This line links Kyoto with Tanba Province, Tajima Province and cities of the Sanin region.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin としました。Sanin region としました。

sen.j: 2002年にこれまで最長だったJR東日本東北本線のうち、盛岡～八戸間が東北新幹線八戸駅開業に伴い、IGRいわて銀河鉄道・青い森鉄道に転換されて分断されたため、山陰本線が営業キロ交通に関する日本一の一覧鉄道の路線となった。
sen.e: In 2002 when the Tohoku Shinkansen was extended to Hachinohe Station, Morioka⇔ Hachinohe section of the Tohoku Main Line, then the longest line, was separated from the line and converted to the lines of Iwate Galaxy Railway Co.,Ltd. and Aomori Railway Company Co., Ltd. and as a result, the San'in Main Line became the longest ichiran railway line in Japan in terms of operation kilometers.
sen.cmt: 一覧鉄道→ichiran railway[定訳不明] 営業キロ→operation kilometers[定訳不明]
sen.e: In 2002, when the Tohoku Shinkansen was extended to Hachinohe Station, the Morioka⇔ Hachinohe section of the Tohoku Main Line, then the longest line, was separated from the line and converted to the lines of Iwate Galaxy Railway Co., Ltd., and Aomori Railway Company Co., Ltd.; as a result, the San'in Main Line became the longest ichiran railway line in Japan in terms of operation kilometers.

In 2002, when the Tohoku Shinkansen was extended to Hachinohe Station, the section between Morioka and Hachinohe of the Tohoku Main Line, then the longest line, was separated from the line and converted to the lines of Iwate Galaxy Railway Co., Ltd., and Aomori Railway Company Co., Ltd.; as a result, the Sanin Main Line became the longest railway line in Japan in terms of operation kilometers.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin としました。原文のwikiを参照したところ、「一覧鉄道」という文字はリンク先の説明のようですので、削除しました。

sen.j: ただし、支線部分を合算した場合は東海道本線の方が長い。
sen.e: However, the Tokaido Main Line is longer if the portion of branch lines is added up.
However, the Tokaido Main Line is longer if the portion of branch lines is combined.
However, the Tokaido Main Line is longer if the portion of branch lines is combined.

sen.j: 営業キロこそ日本最長の路線ではあるが、起点から終点までを通して走る優等列車の設定が史上一度もない本線の一つ（他に中央本線、筑豊本線）となっている。
sen.e: Although it is the longest line in terms of operation kilometers, it is one of main lines on which a superior train that runs from the starting station through the terminal station has never been set on a schedule (other examples are the Chuo Main Line and the Chikuho Main Line)

sen.j: 京都～園部間は、京都より舞鶴市をめざし建設を進めた京都鉄道が1899年までに開通させたものである。
sen.e: By 1899, Kyoto Electric Railway, which had strived to construct the railway connecting Kyoto and Maizuru City, completed Kyoto⇔Sonobe section.
By 1899, the Kyoto Electric Railway, which had worked to construct a railway connecting Kyoto and Maizuru City, completed the Kyoto⇔Sonobe section.
By 1899, the Kyoto Electric Railway, which had worked to construct a railway connecting Kyoto and Maizuru City, completed the Kyoto - Sonobe section.

sen.j: 園部～綾部間は日露戦争を控え、軍都・舞鶴までの建設を急いだ政府が京都鉄道に代わって建設したもの。
sen.e: Sonobe⇔Ayabe section was constructed by the Government which was in hurry to extend the line to Maizuru, the site of naval base, in preparation for Japanese -Russo War.
The Sonobe⇔Ayabe section was constructed by the government, which was in hurry to extend the line to Maizuru, the site of a naval base, in preparation for the Japanese-Russo War.
The Sonobe - Ayabe section was constructed by the government, which was in hurry to extend the line to Maizuru, the site of a naval base, in preparation for the Japanese-Russo War.

sen.j: また福知山～綾部間は阪鶴鉄道の路線を延伸する形で舞鶴までを結ぶ阪鶴線の一部として1904年に開業した。
sen.e: Fukuchiyama⇔Ayabe section came into operation in 1904 as the extension of Hankaku Railway's Hankaku Line that connects to Maizuru.
The Fukuchiyama⇔Ayabe section came into operation in 1904 as an extension of the Hankaku Railway's Hankaku Line, which connects to Maizuru.
The Fukuchiyama - Ayabe section came into operation in 1904 as an extension of the Hankaku Railway's Hankaku Line, which connects to Maizuru.

sen.j: 京都鉄道・阪鶴鉄道の両社は国有化され、京都～綾部間が京都線として1910年に開通した。
sen.e: Lator on, both Kyoto Electric Raiway and Hankaku Railway were nationalized and Kyoto⇔Ayabe section came into operation as Kyoto Line.
Subsequently, the Kyoto Electric Railway and Hankaku Railway were nationalized and the Kyoto⇔Ayabe section came into operation as the Kyoto Line.
Subsequently, the Kyoto Electric Railway and Hankaku Railway were nationalized and the Kyoto - Ayabe section came into operation as the Kyoto Line in 1910.
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。1910を追加しました。

sen.j: 福知山～和田山～香住間は山陽鉄道が開通させた現在の播但線を延伸する形で1911年までに開通した。
sen.e: Fukuchiyama⇔Wadayama⇔Kasumi section came into operation by 1911 as the extension of current Bantan Line that was constructed by San'yo Railway Company.
The Fukuchiyama⇔Wadayama⇔Kasumi section came into operation by 1911 as an extension of what is now the Bantan Line, which was constructed by the San'yo Railway Company.
The Fukuchiyama - Wadayama - Kasumi section came into operation by 1911 as an extension of what is now the Bantan Line, which was constructed by the Sanyo Railway Company.
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanyoとしました。

sen.j: 浜坂～出雲今市（現在の出雲市）間は山陰初の鉄道として1909年に官営で開業した御来屋～米子～境（現在の境港）間を東西に延伸して1911年までに開業した。
sen.e: Hamasaka⇔Izumoimaichi (Izumoshi Station) section came into operation in 1911 by extending, both eastward and westward, the state-operated line which had came into operation in 1909 as the first railway in San'in area and connected Mikuriya Station⇔Yonago Station⇔Sakai Station (Sakaiminato Station).

The Hamasaka⇔Izumoimaichi (Izumoshi Station) section came into operation in 1911 by extending, both eastward and westward, the state-operated line that had came into operation in 1909 as the first railway in the San'in area, and connected Mikuriya Station⇔Yonago Station⇔Sakai Station (Sakaiminato Station).

The Hamasaka - Izumoimaichi (present Izumoshi Station) section came into operation in 1911 by extending, both eastward and westward, the state-operated line that had come into operation in 1909 as the first railway in the Sanin region, and connected Mikuriya Station - Yonago Station - Sakai Station (present Sakaiminato Station).
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。Came →come としました。Present Izumoshi Station としました。Sanin region としました。

sen.j: 翌年、余部橋りょう、桃観トンネルの完成により、香住～浜坂間が開業し京都～出雲今市間が山陰本線となった。
sen.e: Thanks to the completion of Amarube bridge and Tokan tunnel in the following year, Kasumi⇔Hamasaka section came into operation and as a result, Kyoto⇔Izumoimaichi section became the San'in Main Line.

Thanks to the completion of Amarube Bridge and Tokan Tunnel in the following year, the Kasumi⇔Hamasaka section came into operation; consequently, the Kyoto⇔Izumoimaichi section became the San'in Main Line.

Thanks to the completion of Amarube Bridge and Tokan Tunnel in the following year, the Kasumi - Hamasaka section came into operation; consequently, the Kyoto - Izumoimaichi section became the Sanin Main Line.
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。アポストロフィーを削除し、Saninとしました。

sen.j: 出雲今市からは順次西へ延び、1928年に須佐駅まで延伸される。
sen.e: The line was extended stepwise from Izumoimaichi westward and extended to Susa Station in 1928.
The line was extended stepwise from Izumoimaichi westward and then to Susa Station in 1928.
The line was extended stepwise from Izumoimaichi westward and then to Susa Station in 1928.

sen.j: 宇田郷～正明市（現在の長門市）～阿川間および正明市～仙崎は美禰線（美祢線）を延伸する形で1930年までに開業した。
sen.e: Utago Station ⇔Shomyoichi Station (Nagatoshi Station)⇔Agawa Station section and Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section came into operation by 1930 as the extension of the Mine Line (Mine Line).
Utago Station ⇔Shomyoichi Station (Nagatoshi Station)⇔Agawa Station section and Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section came into operation by 1930 as the extension of the Mine Line (Mine Line).
Utago - Shomyoichi (present Nagatoshi Station) - Agawa section and Shomyoichi - Senzaki section came into operation by 1930 as the extension of the Mine Line (Mine Line).
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。Station を削除しました。

sen.j: 小串～幡生間は山陽電気軌道の路線を1925年に国有化したもので、小串線と称していた。
sen.e: Kogushi Station⇔Hatabu Station section had been owned by San'yo Denki Kido but it was nationalized in 1925 and named the Kogushi Line.
The Kogushi Station⇔Hatabu Station section had been owned by San'yo Denki Kido, but it was nationalized in 1925 and renamed as the Kogushi Line.
The Kogushi - Hatabu section had been owned by Sanyo Denki Kido, but it was nationalized in 1925 and renamed as the Kogushi Line.
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanyoとしました。Station を削除しました。

sen.j: 1928年に阿川駅まで延伸された。
sen.e: The line was extended to Agawa Station in 1928.
The line was extended to Agawa Station in 1928.
The line was extended to Agawa Station in 1928.

sen.j: 1933年に須佐～宇田郷間が開業し、美禰線の宇田郷～正明市～阿川間・正明市～仙崎間と小串線を編入して京都～幡生間・正明市～仙崎間となった山陰本線が全通した。
sen.e: In 1933, Susa Station⇔Utago Station section came into operation and by incorporating Mine Line's Utago Station⇔ Shomyoichi Station⇔Agawa Station section/ Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section as well as the Kogushi Line, the entire portion of the San'in Main Line that consists of Kyoto Station ⇔Hatabu Station section and Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section opened.

In 1933, the Susa Station⇔Utago Station section came into operation and by incorporating the Mine Line's Utago Station⇔ Shomyoichi Station⇔Agawa Station section/Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section as well as the Kogushi Line, the entire portion of the San'in Main Line consisting of the Kyoto Station ⇔Hatabu Station section and Shomyoichi Station⇔Senzaki Station section opened.

In 1933, the Susa - Utago section came into operation and by incorporating the Mine Line's Utago - Shomyoichi - Agawa section/Shomyoichi - Senzaki section as well as the Kogushi Line, the entire portion of the Sanin Main Line consisting of the Kyoto - Hatabu section and Shomyoichi - Senzaki section opened.
sen.cmt: ⇔→ - と変更しました。アポストロフィーを削除し、Saninとしました。Station を削除しました。

sen.j: なお、長州鉄道の国有化されなかった幡生～東駅間は、のちに山陽電気軌道（路面電車線、現在はサンデン交通というバス (交通機関)会社）の路線となった。
sen.e: Later on, Hatabu Station～Higashi Station section of Choshu Railway, the portion that was not nationalized, became the line of San'yo Denki Kido (tramway company, current Sanden Kotsu, a bus company).

Eventually, the Hatabu Station～Higashi Station section of the Choshu Railway, being the portion that was not nationalized, became a line of San'yo Denki Kido (a tramway company, currently the Sanden Kotsu bus company).

tit.j: 門司発福知山行き昼行普通列車「824列車」
tit.e: Daytime Local train "824 Train" from Moji to Fukuchiyama
The "824 Train" daytime local train from Moji to Fukuchiyama
The "824 Train" daytime local train from Moji to Fukuchiyama

sen.j: かつて、山陰本線・山陽本線の門司駅～福知山駅間には日本一の走行距離を有する普通列車が運行されていた。
sen.e: In the past, a local train of which running distance was the longest in Japan ran between Moji Station of the San'yo Main Line and Fukuchiyama Station of the San'in Main Line.
In the past, a local train whose running distance was the longest in Japan ran between Moji Station of the San'yo Main Line and Fukuchiyama Station of the San'in Main Line.
In the past, a local train whose running distance was the longest in Japan ran between Moji Station of the Sanyo Main Line and Fukuchiyama Station of the Sanin Main Line.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Sanin, Sanyoとしました。

sen.j: 鉄道ファンはその列車番号で824列車と呼んでいた。
sen.e: Railway enthusiasts called this train 824 Train.
Railway enthusiasts called this the 824 Train.
Railway enthusiasts called this the 824 Train.

sen.j: そもそも昭和30年代まで、日本国有鉄道においては特別急行列車・急行列車の本数が少なかった半面で、長距離の普通列車が設定されていた。
sen.e: Before 1960's, Japan National Railway operated long-distance Local trains while the number of Limited Express and Express was small.
Prior to the 1960s, the Japan National Railway operated long-distance local trains while the number of limited express and express trains was small.
Prior to the mid-1960s, the Japan National Railway operated long-distance local trains while the number of limited express and express trains was small.

sen.j: 1956年11月19日国鉄ダイヤ改正当時だと、東海道本線・山陽本線では東京駅～門司駅間運転の111・112列車（東海道本線区間で夜行列車運転、運転区間の営業キロは1102.8km。「ムーンライトながら」の項目も参照）。
sen.e: As of November 19, 1956 when Japan National Railway's revised schedule was put into place, 111・112 train ran between Tokyo and Moji via the Tokaido Main Line and the San'yo Main Line (ran as night train in the section of Tokaido Main Line, running distance was 1102.8km, also refer to the item of "Moonlight Nagara").

As of November 19, 1956, when the Japan National Railway's revised schedule was implemented, 111・112 train ran between Tokyo and Moji via the Tokaido Main Line and the San'yo Main Line (ran as a night train in the section of the Tokaido Main Line, whose running distance was 1102.8km); also, refer to the item of "Moonlight Nagara").

As of November 19, 1956, when the Japan National Railway's revised schedule was implemented, 111 and 112 trains ran between Tokyo and Moji via the Tokaido Main Line and the Sanyo Main Line (ran as a night train in the section of the Tokaido Main Line, whose running distance was 1102.8 km); also, refer to the section of 'Moonlight Nagara').
sen.cmt: 111 and 112 trains としました。Sanyoとしました。

sen.j: 日本海縦貫線では大阪駅～青森駅間には羽越線を夜行で走る511・512列車、北陸線と奥羽線で2夜行になる513・514列車（運転区間の当時の営業キロは1055.6km）が存在するといった具合である。
sen.e: As for the line running across the coast of Japan Sea, 511・512 train, which ran as night train in the section of the Uetsu Line, and 513・514 train (then running distance was 1055.6km), which ran as night train twice in the section of the Hokuriku Line and the Ou Line, ran between Osaka and Aomori.
sen.cmt: 日本海縦貫線→line running across the coast of Japan Sea[固有名詞ではないと解釈いたしました] 「一原文一訳文の例外処理」
sen.e: As for the line running across the coast of the Sea of Japan, the 511・512 train, which ran as a night train in the section of the Uetsu Line, and the 513・514 train (which then had a running distance of 1055.6km), which ran as a night train twice in the section of the Hokuriku Line and the Ou Line, ran between Osaka and Aomori.

As for the line running across the coast of the Sea of Japan, the 511 and 512 trains, which ran as a night train in the section of the Uetsu Line, and the 513 and 514 trains (which then had a running distance of 1055.6 km), which ran as a night train twice in the section of the Hokuriku Line and the Ou Line, ran between Osaka and Aomori.

sen.j: しかし、1961年10月に実施された「サンロクトオ」と呼ばれるダイヤ改正以降、国鉄では普通列車の乗客を新たに新設ないしは増発した特急・急行列車に振り向けるため、これら長距離運転をする普通列車を削減するようになっていった。
sen.e: After revised schedule called "Sanrokuto" was put into place in October, 1961, Japan National Railway reduced the number of such long-distance Local trains aiming to draw Local trains' passengers to Limited Express and Express which JNR newly introduced or increased the frequency of operation.

After the revised schedule called "Sanrokuto" was put into place in October 1961, the Japan National Railway reduced the number of such long-distance local trains in an effort to draw local trains' passengers to the limited express and express trains that JNR had newly introduced, or it increased the frequency of operation.

After the revised schedule called "Sanrokuto" was put into place in October 1961, the Japan National Railway reduced the number of such long-distance local trains in an effort to draw local trains' passengers to the limited express and express trains that JNR had newly introduced, or it increased the frequency of operation.

sen.j: そして、その普通列車削減の流れが進んだ昭和50年代に、日本一の運行距離を有する普通列車（鈍行）として鉄道ファンに注目されるようになったのが、この824列車である。
sen.e: In the 1970's when the number of Local trains had already been reduced considerably, this 824 train attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts as the Local train (slow train) that runs the longest distance in Japan.

In the 1970s, when the number of local trains had already been considerably reduced, this 824 train attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts as the local train (slow train) that ran the longest distance in Japan.

From the mid-1970s to the mid-1980's, when the number of local trains had already been considerably reduced, this 824 train attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts as the local train (slow train) that ran the longest distance in Japan.
sen.cmt: 昭和50年代→From the mid-1970s to the mid-1980's としました。

sen.j: 以前には全線を直通する夜行列車もあったが、夜行区間が格上げ（急行「しまね」を経て夜行「さんべ」）されたり、夜行区間と昼行区間とが別列車に分断（夜行区間は後の「山陰」）されて、この列車が生き残った。
sen.e: Although some night trains had run through whole line, only this train survived after trains used in the night train section was upgraded (to Express "Shimane"and eventually to night train "Sanbe") or trains used in the night train section and the day train section were split (trains used in the night train section was named "San'in" later on).

Although some night trains had run through whole line, only this train survived after trains used in the night train section was upgraded (to Express "Shimane"and eventually to night train "Sanbe") or trains used in the night train section and the day train section were split (trains used in the night train section was named "San'in" later on).

Although some night trains had run through whole line, only this train survived after trains used in the night train section was upgraded (to Express 'Shimane' and eventually to night train 'Sanbe') or trains used in the night train section and the day train section were split (trains used in the night train section was named 'Sanin' later on).

sen.j: このため、本列車のダイヤグラム鉄道におけるダイヤ自体は山陰線全通時にまでさかのぼる（戦時中は分断）が、日本最長となったのは、それまで最長だった大阪駅発新潟駅行きの普通列車が廃止された1961年-1975年の国鉄ダイヤ改正1972年（昭和47年）であった。
sen.e: Although the time schedule of this train dates back to the time when the whole portion of San'in Main Line opened (it was split during wartime), it became the longest distance train in Japan when the Local train running from Osaka Station to Niigata Station, then the longest distance train, was abolished by the Japan National Railway's schedule revision 1972 that was implemented as part of a series of revisions made during 1961-1975.
sen.cmt: 1961年-1975年の国鉄ダイヤ改正1972年（昭和47年）→[原文の意味が不明ですが、左記英文のように解釈いたしました。ご検討ください]
sen.e: Although the time schedule of this train dates back to the period when the entire portion of the San'in Main Line opened (it was split during wartime), it became the longest-distance train in Japan when the local train running from Osaka Station to Niigata Station, then the train running the longest distance, was abolished through the Japan National Railway's schedule revision of 1972, which was implemented as part of a series of revisions made during the period of 1961 to 1975.

Although the time schedule of this train dates back to the period when the entire portion of the Sanin Main Line opened (it was split during wartime), it became the longest-distance train in Japan when the local train running from Osaka Station to Niigata Station, then the train running the longest distance, was abolished through the Japan National Railway's schedule revision of 1972, which was implemented as part of a series of revisions made during the period of 1961 to 1975.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを削除し、Saninとしました。

sen.j: この列車は門司駅を朝5時半頃に発ち、福知山駅にはその日が終わる頃に到着するもので、途中駅で特急・急行の待避や荷物輸送のための長時間停車をしていたこともあって、所要時間は約18時間半にもなり、表定速度は30kmを若干上回る程度であった。
sen.e: This train departs from Moji Station around 5:30 in the morning and arrives at Fukuchiyama Station around the end of the day and it takes around 18 and half hours, of which running speed is slightly over 30km/h, because of waiting time for the passing of Limited Express/Express and prolonged stopping required for freight transportation.

This train departs from Moji Station at around 5:30 in the morning and arrives at Fukuchiyama Station at around the end of the day; it takes approximately 18.5 hours at a running speed of slightly over 30 km/h, because of the waiting time for the passing of limited express/express trains and the prolonged stopping required for freight transportation.

This train departs from Moji Station at around 5:30 in the morning and arrives at Fukuchiyama Station at around the end of the day; it takes approximately 18.5 hours at a running speed of slightly over 30 km/h, because of the waiting time for the passing of limited express/express trains and the prolonged stopping required for freight transportation.

sen.j: また、客車は国鉄オハ35系客車・国鉄スハ43系客車・国鉄60系客車など手動扉の旧型のものが最後まで使用された。
sen.e: Until it ceased to run, this train used outmoded passenger cars with hand-operated doors such as JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Oha 35, JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Suha 43 and JNR/JR Passenger Car Series 60.

Until it ceased to run, this train used outmoded passenger cars with hand-operated doors, such as the JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Oha 35, JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Suha 43 and JNR/JR Passenger Car Series 60.

Until it ceased to run, this train used outmoded passenger cars with hand-operated doors, such as the JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Oha 35, JNR/JR Passenger Car Series Suha 43 and JNR/JR Passenger Car Series 60.

sen.j: その旧型客車の旅愁と運転区間が相まって、「乗り鉄」とも通称された鉄道旅行派のファンなどから注目される存在となり、宮脇俊三・種村直樹といった紀行作家による乗車記も書かれた。
sen.e: Because of a mood while travelling on such outmoded passenger cars along with its long running distance, this line attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts, so-called "Noritetsu", and books describing the memory of boarding were written by travel writers like Shuzo MIYAWAKI and Naoki TANEMURA.

Because of the mood while traveling in such outmoded passenger cars along with its long running distance, this line attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts, or so-called "Noritetsu," and books describing the memories of boarding were written by travel writers such as Shuzo MIYAWAKI and Naoki TANEMURA.

Because of the mood while traveling in such outmoded passenger cars along with its long running distance, this line attracted the attention of railway enthusiasts, or so-called 'Noritetsu,' and books describing the memories of boarding were written by travel writers such as Shunzo MIYAWAKI and Naoki TANEMURA.
sen.cmt: " → ' としました。人名を修正しました。

sen.j: しかし客車の老朽化が進んだことと、国鉄合理化政策の一環として客車列車を気動車・電車化した上で運行距離を短縮する施策が取られるようになったことから、824列車は1984年2月1日国鉄ダイヤ改正で下関駅～出雲市駅間運行の824列車と、出雲市駅～福知山駅間運行の548列車に系統が分割された。
sen.e: Because of the aging of passenger cars as well as the policy, which was adopted as part of rationalization of Japan National Railway, of shortening running distance with using diesel cars and/or electric cars, 824 train was split into two, namely 824 train that runs between Shimonoseki Station and Izumoshi Station and 548 train that runs between Izumoshi Station and Fukuchiyama Station, by JNR's schedule revision implemented as of February 1, 1984.

Because of the aging of passenger cars as well as the policy, which had been adopted as part of the rationalization of the Japan National Railway, in order to shorten the running distance when using diesel cars and/or electric cars, the 824 train was split into two, namely the 824 train that runs between Shimonoseki Station and Izumoshi Station and the 548 train that runs between Izumoshi Station and Fukuchiyama Station, by JNR's schedule revision implemented on February 1, 1984.

Because of the aging of passenger cars as well as the policy, which had been adopted as part of the rationalization of the Japan National Railway, in order to shorten the running distance when using diesel cars and/or electric cars, the 824 train was split into two, namely the 824 train that runs between Shimonoseki Station and Izumoshi Station and the 548 train that runs between Izumoshi Station and Fukuchiyama Station, by JNR's schedule revision implemented on February 1, 1984.

sen.j: その後、更に列車の運行区間が細分化され、2006年現在では824列車が運行していた時間帯に該当する列車が存在しない区間もある。
sen.e: Running section of this train has been further subdivided since then and as of 2006, in some sections, no trains run during time zone when 824 train used to run.
The running section of this train has been further subdivided since then, and as of 2006, in some sections, no trains run during the time period when the 824 train used to run.
